doc_title: 1. Yoshua Bengio: Debating AI Safety Risks
claim: International treaties and hardware-enabled governance (e.g., restricting high-end training chips) are important avenues to reduce global catastrophic risk, but they face serious verification and circumvention challenges and must be accompanied by defense-in-depth measures, cyber/physical security, and equitable provisions to include and benefit the Global South.
explanation: The claim is well supported by current expert literature: many policy papers and researchers argue international agreements and hardware-focused measures (e.g., limits on high-end training chips or compute caps) are important tools for reducing extreme AI/dual-use risks. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.20563?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) It is also well documented that export controls and hardware restrictions face serious verification, enforcement, and circumvention problems (multilateral coverage, supply‑chain chokepoints, smuggling/diversion, and compliance burdens). ([csis.org](https://www.csis.org/analysis/understanding-us-allies-current-legal-authority-implement-ai-and-semiconductor-export?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [itif.org](https://itif.org/publications/2025/01/07/export-controls-on-ai-chips-bidens-overreach-risks-us-leadership-in-tech/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [tomshardware.com](https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/artificial-intelligence/u-s-authorities-allegedly-placed-secret-tracking-devices-in-ai-chip-shipments-to-china-report-claims-targeted-shipments-from-dell-and-super-micro-containing-nvidia-and-amd-chips-had-trackers-in-packaging-and-servers-themselves?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Experts therefore recommend complementary “defense‑in‑depth” measures (cyber/physical security, layered safeguards, incident response) rather than relying on single instruments. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.07933?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Finally, major international bodies stress the need for equitable provisions and capacity‑building for the Global South so governance and benefits aren’t concentrated in wealthy states. ([unesco.org](https://www.unesco.org/en/legal-affairs/recommendation-ethics-artificial-intelligence?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2024/sep/19/global-ai-fund-needed-to-help-developing-nations-tap-tech-benefits-un-says?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) The remaining uncertainty is practical: implementation, political buy‑in, and technical verification are hard—hence the claim is accurate but not unqualified, so not a perfect (100) score.
